Title: Type 3 conditional
References: ALEXANDER, L. G.: Longman English Grammar. 20th edition. New York : Longman publishing, 2003. 351 p.
Content:
Third conditional assumes something purely imaginary in the if-clause and consider the imagined consequences in the main clause.

   The most commonly used form is: If  +  past perfect  +  would have 

(we can use should have, could have, might have instead of would have)

   Imagine: Last week you bought a lottery ticket. But you did not win.

examples:

- If I had won the lottery, I would have bought a car.

- If the weather had been nice, many people would have gone to the beach.

- If I had been taller,I would have joined the police force.
